Last one was 2 years ago EDITION

>Why Taiwan ?
why not ? it's Asia on easy level, tons of friendly people, nicest expat community that isn't weeb or druggies or coomers

>No, seriously, why ?
Great emphasis on industry so all engineers are welcome
They recruit a lot of TEFL and it's relatively well paid compared to the average salary on the island, great if you don't have any student debt to deal with
Taipei is absolutely gorgeous, the skyline may not be up to standards compared to the megacities of Asia but it's a nice place with all the amenities of a world-class city
Rent is relatively cheap compared to the other big places in Asia, easily comparable to Thailand (albeit with a roughly 20% markup)
Street food is cheap and delicious
Taiwan has a rich and multicultural history that allows them to be ok with the concept of being a foreigner

>Is Taiwan the real China ?
No, ROC isn't the real china, it's an offshoot as much as the PRC is. Taiwan has been impacted by japanese culture a lot whereas the PRC modified radically china's culture through the cultural revolution. Both represent significant aspects of the Chinese civilization and you should go to both if you're truly interested.

>How can I immigrate/expatriate/live in Taiwan ?
Work Visa, Working Holiday Visas, Gold Card Visa, Student visa, and Chinese Student visa. and whatever investor scheme i can't be arsed to look up. Always make sure you consult your local Taiwanese embassy (likely referred as a taipei representative office in your country). Keep in mind the latter two make you eligible for a couple of grants and allow you to work (you need a work permit but it's easy to get).

>cooming in taiwan ?
the prostitutes are ridiculously expensive (actually true, a hundred bucks an hour) so please don't come

>Will China bomb Taiwan ?
Not yet. Several conditions must be fulfilled and right now, very few are.

>>2371115
591.com.tw is the way to go but it's in mandarin and the landlord may not want to speak english, but facebook has many facebook groups. The price of 1000$ for a one bedroom appartment is ridiculously high. As for being old buildings, that's pretty much what you're getting in taiwan i'm afraid.

>1500$ per month for the appartment
That's the point of shared rental. You risk more by having more tenants to deal with but you earn more. There rarely is a shared appartment whose combined rents is lower or equal to that of a single rental, so it's far from accurate to get an estimate that way.

It also depends on where you're looking. Lots of rental on da'an and xinyi district but they're expensive and not quite worth it. I usually recommend zhongzheng district as the go to for westerners, it's easier to move and lots of good food and neighborhoods. While being p cheap.

What people do and what i did was to resign myself to a 6 month bail in a shared appt at 300$ then i asked the taiwanese pals i made by then to help me out with facilitating me with the appartment i currently live in, that is tad more modern and great looking for a reasonably cheaper square foot.

>>2371664
>Where can I stay and have a nice time

A guy made a cool map on another thread.

>the problem with the taiwanese downtown is that it spans half the fucking city with many nevralgic centers (Dongmen, Ximen, 101, Technology Building, Main Station, Digital Plaza around Songjiang Nanjing etc.). So as long as you're within the city limits (even if you're not, you're never THAT far), It'll take you as much time to walk to the station than to get to your station of choice. I highly suggest living near the green line (so, the green zone) because that practically gets you anywhere and is well connected to the red Line (which basically covers the more expensive Da'an area). You could also consider living up north where the black area is. This is where a lot of older expats live, but i don't know much about it besides Yuanshan with its Maji Square (and its Triangle)

You want cheap but nice addresses, look around Wanshan and Zhongzheng District. If that's too much, you can still settle for something around Xindian without missing out on the rest of Taipei since it's not that far. Also, the 648 bus basically goes from the deeper end of xindian all the way to City Hall, so even if you're a cheap hack you can make do with that. Because yes, knowing how the buses work in Taipei will save you a *lot* of money.

I've lived in Singapore for a few years now, and i'd say that nothing really feels like the rest of Asia. There is some nostalgia in play with this one with no real way of having my childhood memories ruined as there is almost no footage of it, very few people rode it and it closed decades ago but I remember Ghost Hunt at Sega-World Trocadero being incredible.

You went around a haunted house with physical sets and ghosts would appear and interact with them, you'd then shoot the ghosts. I remember one scene had you stop in front of a wall, you'd see the bricks bulge, sprout eyes, and fly at you. If you did well enough, your car went around for a second lap where the scenes differed and you'd fight the final boss (a devil), if you beat that boss you got to have your photo taken. In retrospect it was massively ahead of its time with the use of AR

Only footage I can find is a tiny segment at 20:10 in this vid: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fDNKPoCy42M&t=20m10s

You fucking nailed it. I mentioned this in a previous thread but I think the biggest thing that Wizarding World fucking nails is the wish fulfillment aspect. HP has a rabid fanbase that wishes they got their Hogwarts invitations and shit, and now they can pretend they actually did and do all the things they dreamed of when reading the books/watching the movies. There's personal stakes there. I remember there was talk about Epic Universe a while back and someone was wondering why they decided to go for a How to Train Your Dragon-themed land when Dreamworks has so many different IPs they could use, why limit it to just that one. It's the same thing. You could argue Shrek is by far the most famous and well-known Dreamworks property, but people aren't wishing they could live in the swamp or hang out with these fairy tale weirdoes. They like it as a movie and that's it. HTTYD is not only probably the most critically well regarded franchise they have, but it also has a big core fanbase like HP (albeit not as huge), but it most importantly fulfills that wish fulfillment aspect. The dragons in the movies (especially Toothless) are lovable and cute and make people want them, but also literally everyone has dreamed about flying at some point in their lives. Being able to fly on the back of a dragon is just such a simple idea that hits an extremely large group of people. I think that's one of the big reasons people love Flight of Passage despite the fact people are mostly lukewarm on the Avatar franchise.

posts.com:
If you line up two hours before that nights show, outside the opera house you can get standing room tickets. Go for the 18 Euro spots, but you can get ‘em as cheap as 13 Euro. You should only have to wait 40-60 minutes or so in line, and then you can kill the remaining hour outside at the cafes (standing spots are assigned). The opera comes with subtitles that are displayed on a tablet in front of you in the language of your choice. Hanging out in the building alone is worth it, but it is an amazing experience if you’re in to the arts.
Honorable mention to the Upper Belvedere Palace and the Schonbrunn Palace.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you wanna visit a comfy town, you can take the ferry from Batangas to Romblon. The town is fairly small, yet charming. Just a short motorcycle-ride away, you got Bonbon beach which is usually quite pristine, and you also have Logbon island just a short boat-ride away.

Besides, this is the marble capital of the country, so you can buy nice marble figures and misc. for quite cheap. There's also an Italian restaurant there ran by an actual Italian with pizza that tastes quite good considering the logistical implications of running it there.
Although the island is quite small, you can take a small ferry to Tablas which has lot's of nice beaches around and some outdoor activites, or to Sibuyan which is less developed but has a 2,000m mountain that is quite challenging to hike(takes 2 days), so if hiking is your thing, check that one out. Also Cresta de Gallo is one of my favourite islands.

>>2372901
That's Inambakan in Southern Cebu. Very nice falls consiting of 3 levels. However, not too far away is also Dao Falls(pic related) which is much more majestic, and requires a 30min trek along the stunning river that leads up to it. Almost straight out of a fairytale.
To get to either of these, you can avail of either a tour agency in Moalboal, or if you are not a complete retard on a scooter, you can rent one and go by yourself.

>Would like to a do a few things off the beaten path if possible, any recommendations?
In Bohol, go to Dimiao. There are 4 popular waterfalls there, and it's quite far so barely any tourists there either. You may come accross Kuya RJay, the tour guide there. He's pretty cool and fun. Tell him you hate Russians and he will love you.
If you have time, check out Anda Beach, pretty nice. Also it's close to Cam-Umantad falls and some kino rice terraces.
DON'T RIDE IN THE DARK YOU ARE PLAYING WITH THE DEVIL IF SO. And I'm not talking about getting robbed, I am talking about the traffic hazards, like poorly lit roads that could have obstacles in them that you can't see, borderline psychopathic bus and van-drivers, dogs suddenly running accross the road infront of you.

cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2372901
>>2373189

>Loboc river seems interesting but I've heard mixed reviews about river cruise
It's cool to do once, but that's about it. There are some paved roads that go along the river or close to it so you can check out through that.

>Also chocolate hills and tarsiers... is it crowded and touristy?
Barely any tourists in the Tarsier Sanctuary last time I was there. Be sure to go early.
Chocolate Hills can get quite crowded. However, there's a "secret" area though that you can go to. You can climb ontop of one of the hills there right by the road and have a great view. Pic related
Not too far from the Chocolate Hills there's something called Pangas Falls.

>Also places for food/entertainment, I will try anything.
In Cebu City, check out 8flix & Chill. There they serve Tuslob Buwa. To spoil it for you, it's basically pork brain mixed with chili, onion and onions sauce. It turns into a gravy which you dip "puso", or rice balls in. As disgusting as it might sound to most, it's actually really good. Imagine dipping bread in a buttery gravy full of umami. That's pretty much what it is. It's dirt cheap too, $4 for 10 piece of rice balls and unlimited gravy.
Top of Cebu is another nice restaurant to check out.

In Bohol, Mist is a cool interesting restaurant made in the vernacular style. Molly Bistro is similar, though they primarily serve a Filipino/Viet BBQ fusion.
Bamboo place is usually where the nightlife is in Alona/Tawala.
Be on the lookout for Beefarm Ice cream along Alona Beach. Really delicious. And on that topic, The Buzzz Cafe is pretty nice. Check out Halang Halang, a Bisaya soup similar to Tom Kha Gai.

If you go to Balicasag, don't fucking eat anything there. I am an advocate for promoting Filipino food and even I found the food there very mediocre. Also it's a ripoff, $10 for a single plate of an awful meal. If they still sell barbecue in Virgin Island, I suggest you to avoid the touts. It's good but extremely overpriced.

Cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2372901
>>2373189
>>2373197

>Worth it to rent motorbikes everywhere or is it dangerous?
If you have common sense, you'll be fine most likely. Don't drive like a maniac, get used to the bike first. Don't do steep turns(if you know how to truly countersteer) if there is dust or dirt on the road. Keep an eye on the rear mirrors. If you see a van, bus or any big car approaching you fast, steer to the right shoulder to let them pass. These drivers have no brains, but you don't want them to harm you either.
Before you rent a bike, check that both the front and rear brakes are good, that means you shouldn't have to squeeze/press them too hard to actually stop. Check for air in the tyres, they should be rock hard.
Ask the renters to check oil.
Honk whenever you are passing someone, or think someone who is at perpendicular interchange haven't seen. Use the horn alot to let people know you are there.
Bohol and Siquijor are great places to rent. Coron you won't really need.

>Any way to avoid food poisoning or should I just bring Cipro and pray?
I honestly think it all depends on your gut most of the time. I've been food poisoned here a few times but that was after staying here for many months. Meanwhile, my friend and his gf was here for only 4 days and they both got food poisoned, but not me. But yeah, you are likely to experience some kind of diarrhea sooner or later

cont.

posts.com:
>>2372901
>>2373189
>>2373197
>>2373200
>Any other tips/advice for Philippines I'd appreciate.
Use Grab when going around in the cities. Taxi drivers in this region is notorious for ripping people off, although I ironically had no problem using Taxis in Cebu City, the 3 drivers were honest and used a non-rigged meter.
A 10min ride with tricycle should not cost more than P150-200. If they say anything above, haggle or just go for another driver.
Don't be swayed by touts, be on the look for the best deal. If you can't find, give in to them and hear what they offer.
Ignore hawkers unless they have something you really need and can't acquire easily in that moment, eg. drybag.
I suggest you learn how to use the "tabo" when taking a shit. It will save you space not having to bring rolls everywhere.
Don't be afraid to ask locals for directions.
There are probably more stuff but I can't recall much right now.

>Would like to a do a few things off the beaten path if possible, any recommendations?
About Coron, if you have time and money, do a Dugon tour. It's one of my favourite activites I've ever done. Contact this guy for more info:
https://www.instagram.com/freedivewithlouie/

There are also alot of Japanese shipwrecks there from WWII that are worth to check out if you have your scuba cert in place. I think they will only let you dive in the cargo ship as it's very easy to traverse.

If you can bump rent to $1000 AUD then lots of nice places in KL will open up. Penang is a bit trickier since there's mostly local stuff for long term lease or expensive stuff for short term lease geared towards foreigners.

I've lived in both KL and Penang, neither are perfect. Food is God tier in both although Penang probably has better local food.

Which one you prefer depends on what sort of city you like. KL is basically a big spreadout city of shopping centres and apartments, Penang is more organic, although it's still pretty chaotic on the roads.

I used to eat heaps at nasi kandar places and the cost never came to more than 9 ringies ($3).

Regarding dating, Chinese are more open about it but have higher standards. If you struggle back in Aus then you'll struggle with them. Malays are shy in public but love white guys in private.

Never worked out in KL so I can't really help there, although I'm sure KLCC is full of more corporate type gyms. KL is a bit like Canberra in that it's spread out over a big distance and every area is a little different. There are nice expat areas far from the CBD where more corporate/government expats live.

AirBnB is a good place for short term stuff, even month to month stuff. I've stayed at Summer Suites Residences a few times for shorter stays and that's a good place to start. Walking distance to KLCC, Chow Kit, etc. Near metro and monorail if you want to go further.

I had a friend hook me up with an apartment there last time, so I'm not sure about longer leases. It's an easy place to get monthly stays at a reasonable price though. Since many apartments are 3 bedroom you'll find heaps of places to share if that's your thing.

Regarding the Chinese girls, they just seemed very interested in money and status. Often asked what I did, what I was doing there, where I lived. They just felt harder to game. Malay girls are more care free and just want a good time. Being friendly to them was enough. Las Vegas has some of the best entertainment and dining in the world, and you never have to set foot in a casino (although I would just to see the freaks that haunt the floor, it’s great people-watching).

Asking “any good food” is impossibly broad, it depends on what you’re looking for and what your budget is. I like Craftsteak at the MGM, Julian Serrano at the Aria, and (of course) you should do at least one buffet, Caesar’s is famous for a reason.

Zak Bagan’s Haunted Museum looks interesting, lots of spoopy artifacts. I haven’t gone but it’s on my list.

And then of course you can catch a show. I’m a Beatles fan so I’ve seen Love at the Mirage a few times — but there are literally hundreds to choose from. Sometimes it’s fun to catch a random comic who you would never seek out… like Carrot Top does a fucking hilarious show, actually.

Lastly, those gun ranges where you go and pay $200 to pop a glock 10 times… incredibly overrated and overpriced BUT if you’ve got a younger kid around, it will be the highlight of the trip for him. I actually really enjoyed taking a young cousin to Battlefield and letting him rail on the full auto BAR.

posts.com:
I moved to China in 2019, and travelled around a lot of the country. I'm so glad that I got to see as much as I did before the omicron lockdowns starting in Jan 2021.

China was so much fun before covid, and even at the time long time expats were telling me the glory days were long gone. I can only imagine what it was like back in circa 2010.

Hopefully we get a return to the glory days, but I'm not crossing my fingers. It seems like the this trend is true for all of Asia. Thailand, and even Cambodia just don't feel very exotic anymore. I blame the internet for not only demystifying those countries, but also spreading a monoculture, that is slowly turning every country into a carbon copy of each other.

China, because it is semi-insulated from the web, is still a bit of a wild card. However the rise of nationalism really put a damper on travel in the 国

>>2367481
Depends what you are looking for

Cities here are much less Aesthetic than you can find on the Continent, only Bath stands out off the top of my head.

There aren't really any tourist attractions in other cities, unless you are a fan of history in which case there are numerous Cathedrals and Castles, as well as ruined Abbeys, Castles and Roman stuff. However the latter are in remote areas not hugely accessible by train.

That being said, aesthetic and comfy small towns and villages are in veritable abundance.
So if you want to experience the spirit of 'Old England' I would strongly recommend going to the Cotswolds if this is your thing.

As others have said London is a complete shit tip, but there are some worthwhile things to see, you've got the classic landmarks like Westminster Abbey and the Houses of Parliament. There are other great attractions such as the British Museum and National Portrait Gallery which are free and house lots of well known and remarkable stuff.

>>2371256
Everything except for hotels and things offering Christmas meals are closed on the 25th. If you're not worried about a Christmassy meal, lots of Indian restaurants are open and do special banquets. Christmas Eve is usually Sunday opening hours and Boxing Day (26th) is a popular shopping day.

Castles and stately homes vary massively. Big old stone buildings are expensive to heat, lots of stone that gets slippery when damp etc. Some close for the month, some close on off-peak, some have reduced hours. Lots of Stately homes have special christmas events on

Trains will be a nightmare over Christmas.

Why would you commit to a 7 day stay around this time of year when it is off-peak season in almost every locale(except for skiing hotspots)? And then extend it 2 days if you hated it so much?

This is one of the reasons I prefer going to warmer places this time of year, because availability is never an issue, prices are lower and I don't have to get stuck committing to properties. Like an autist I keep only committing to properties for one day and telling reception the next morning if I am extending my stay or not. It is not an issue since reception is rarely busy and they are hurting for business this season.

Sure after you unpack, repacking and moving to another property often takes considerable time and sometimes money(a taxi ride), but it is better than being stuck in a property that may be by a main road or highway so loud that you can't sleep properly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The five ex-Soviet "Stans" aren't as much talked about as other destinations despite offering a lot to visitors.
I have lived and travelled through them, so let me give you an overview in case you're interested.

posts.name: Kazakhstan
posts.com:
The biggest of five countries and also the country with subjectively the least number of obvious tourist attractions.
What makes up for it is the sheer size of the country, you can spend days going across by train and experience the diversity of landscapes from snow-capped mountains, empty steppe to plain old desert.

The big split is between North and South, with the less-visited North featuring the Dubai-esque capital Astana (formerly Nur-Sultan, formerly Astana) and the "Russian" provinces and the Karaganda desert, the South having multiple historical cities dotted along the border.

Most people will visit Almaty, the most successful example of a modernised Soviet city and also the only place where you can eat at western fast-food chains that aren't KFC for a change.
Near Almaty you can find a lot of mountainous nature such as the Big Almaty Lake (pic related), valleys and nature parks towards China but also a glimpse into China at the Khorgos Special Economic Zone where duty is charged by the kilo.
Almaty and Bishkek in Kyrgyzstan are 4 hours and about 10 dollars apart by car, you can easily fly into either city and reach the other on the same day.

A underrated place is the South-West: On the way from or to Uzbekistan you can make a detour for a day trip to newly-renovated Turkestan and Taraz is also worth stopping over for a couple hours.
The highway between Almaty and Shymkent is a racetrack, especially at night, so if you want to keep your nerves just use one of the frequent trains.

Western Kazakhstan is partially located in Europe and can be used as a starting point towards the Caucasus and Russia by low-cost carrier and frequent overnight trains.
On the way you will pass Baikonur, sadly only legally accessible through overpriced tours, launches can be seen from outside, sneaking in can be risky, especially in the current political climate.

posts.name: Kyrgyzstan
posts.com:
The "Switzerland of Central Asia" has the most liberal visa regime, most Westerners will be able to stay for 60 days without any visa or other bureaucratic hurdles.

Everybody will pass through Bishkek, the poorer, more "Soviet" cousin of Almaty, especially if you need a visa for any neighbouring country.
The city itself can be visited in a day, two if you're interested in bazars, Alamedin, Dordoi and Osh bazar being the ones recommended for a comprehensive experience.
The city may be boring to visit but is very comfortable to live due to low price levels and everything a second world dweller being in walking distance.

The main draw of Kyrgyzstan is the nature, be it the surprisingly good ski resort near Karakol, the never-freezing Issyk-Kul, the countless valleys featuring yurts and hot springs, the mountain passes towards the South and the changed Kyrgyz part of the Fergana valley.
If you are fine with not being spoken to in English you can get nature excursions for low, be it guided hikes, ski transfers to yurt stays with optional horse riding.
Try to get excursions with meals prepared by locals, during summer you will usually get loads of fresh vegetables and fruits to complement the meat-laden main dishes.

posts.name: Tajikistan
posts.com:
The non-Turk outlier of the region that is heavily influenced by Persian culture has become more open recently, with most westerners being able to enter visa-free for 30 days.
You still need to get a separate permit to visit the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonmous Oblast, but you should be able to get it on the way in Dushanbe.

Despite being the poorest country (salary-wise), as a tourist you end up spending more money than in neighbouring Kyrgyzstan, be it on transport, accommodation or imported goods.

Tajikistan has some dishes that you cannot find in the surrounding countries, a blessing if you have been in rural areas for a while and are getting tired of plov, samsas and noodles.
Many expats say that Dushanbe feels a bit like Pyongyang, with police checking beards and headwear to prevent extremism from taking root and the limited number of places to go after work where you will end up meeting the same people anyway.

If you're in Tashkent for more than two days and getting bored you can do an overnight trip to Khujand across the border to see what the city would have looked like before the reconstructions.

Because of the border conflict and other border closures you will not be able to enter Kyrgyzstan without taking a detour via Uzbekistan, easy to do from Khujand or Dushanbe, more annoying when you're deep in the GBAO.

posts.name: Turkmenistan
posts.com:
There are two way to see Turkmenistan, the expensive and comprehensive way using a North Korea style tour with a guide and driver or by rushing through the country on a transit visa between Iran and Uzbekistan.
If on a tour everything will be taken care of, just pay the amount requested and enjoy the ride.
If you successfully managed to get a transit visa then you will spend your time and cash moving between towns in trains and shared taxis with locals, haggling with hotels for low rates, bribing officials with dollars and cigarettes (which seem to have become more and more valuable in the last year, an open pack can save you queues and inspections without much suspicion.

The most popular transit visa route is between Urgench/Khiva and Mashad, within three days you can see unique nature (pic related), a historical city and the shiny marble capital.

posts.name: Uzbekistan
posts.com:
In the "Big Three" cities of Samarkand/Bukhara/Khiva you will find the closes to mass tourism, with European boomers spending their retirement money on souvenirs to bring back to their boomer friends.
Still, it's nowhere near the levels of any European tourist city, even at the most popular sites you can just wait five minutes and you'll be only be sharing it with domestic tourists and local touts.

While the Big Three are what draw the most people, on a longer visit you may want to check out more nature-based destinations such as Karakalpakstan, site of what used to be the Aral Sea or the Fergana Valley where the above-mentiond souvenirs are actually made.

Moving between regions can be done by train or by domestic flight via Tashkent.
While the flights are comfortable and not too expensive, you can save money and experience authentic Uzbekistan by taking an overnight train, especially if you book third class (platzkart). If you find out that the experience is too authentic for you, you can easily bribe the conductor to find you a private compartment for about 10 to 15 dollars.

While Tashkent might be your entry point, you will quickly find out that it's a fairly boring city, especially the nightlife when compared to Almaty and Bishkek.
Sadly for the inclined tourist there are less and less Soviet-era buildings left untouched in Tashkent, but a simple trip to any neighbouring country will satisfy your cravings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What you definitely need are some skills reading Cyrillic, even in countries that formally switched to Roman characters.
With only English you won't get as far somebody who speaks just even basic Russian, English services are generally available but come at a premium.
Just using some basic greetings in the respective local languages will usually be met with enthusiasm, even if you then continue in Russian or pidgin English-Russian.

Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan are the two countries where you won't stand out as a white Westerner due to the high number of ethnic Russians, even at bazars you will get the same treatment as locals, at least until you open your mouth. Usually, this will work to your advantage, but be prepared to be talked to in Rapid Russian.

The region has a reputation of being dangerous, mostly due to the proximity to Afghanistan, but as a tourist the biggest risk you'll face is road traffic, some taxi rides will make even the most euphoric atheist pray for a safe journey.

In most cities you can save yourself a lot of trouble by installing the Yandex Taxi app, the local equivalent to Uber. Even just showing the app prices will give you stronger hand while haggling, never use a metered taxi without fixating a price first, it's an invitation to get ripped off.

Tourist SIM cards are available in every country, the easiest being in Kyrgyzstan where they'll just hand them out for free at busy border crossings, the most expensive being in Turkmenistan (and you may not be able to use shitpost on /int/), see the ever-useful Prepaid SIM Card Wiki for more details.

The best English internet site for this region is Caravanistan, some of the articles may become outdated but the forum will usually have the relevant updates.
I'll check this thread for questions and try to answer until this thread dies, so ask away!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>That being said, what’s the best time of the year to visit them?
You can visit all year around, but each region has its "best" season.
The desert parts of Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and the whole of Turkmenistan are best visited in spring and autumn because it can get hot in summer, easily more than 40°C for days, although dry heat, so more bearable than similar humid destinations.
The mountain parts of Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan have their main season in summer when you can hike everywhere and all the summer facilities are open. In winter there are fewer places where you can go skiing and winter hiking, but in early spring and late autumn you'll find many places closed.
TL;DR: summer/winter for mountains, spring/autumn for the rest

>My russian is very very basic, will I survive?
Little Russian is already better than no Russian.
Learn some useful common phrases (e.g. Pimsleur Russian) and download an offline translator. Make sure that you have a Russian keyboard enabled in case somebody wants to translate to English.
I personally make sure to write down any amounts negotiated (especially taxi fares) on paper or on my phone and show them to prevent and misunderstandings or "misunderstandings" (i.e. scams).

>Lastly, what’s that flag chart?
It's the flags of the five countries crossed with each other!
You can see the original flags on the diagonal from top left to bottom right.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>What would be the best order or “loop” to visit the stans?
If you have visa-free access to Uzbekistan I'd pass through there multiple times because you can get to all the other countries from there.
The KG-TJ border is closed and will likely remain closed for the time being, so Tajikistan is pretty much only accessible from Uzbekistan.
Having said that it's all a matter of preference and (time) budget.
If Turkmenistan opens (to how it used to be in 2019) I would enter from Iran on a transit visa via the Mashad-Ashgabat-Khiva route because that way you won't have to worry about carrying large amounts of cash afterwards.
From there I'd do the "Big Three" Khiva->Bukhara->Samarkand before crossing the border to Panjakent (TJ), going down to Dushanbe, the base for planning any activities in the GBAO.
The return from Dushanbe would be via Khujand to Tashkent, if you don't want to do the Anzob twice, you can also go via Termez, possible even by train.
From Tashkent you can either go North to see more desert/steppe in Kazakhstan or East to the Fergana valley, ending up in Osh (KG).
From there you can do the 10-hour ride to Bishkek, stopping over in Toktogul for a night if you want.
In Northern Kyrgyzstan, you will very likely spend some time in Issyk-Kul, both on the lake and the surrounding mountains, stopping over in Karakol before heading towards Almaty, easily reached via Bishkek, the more adventurous and scenic path via the Karakara valley.
From Almaty you can go West to Taraz/Shymkent/Turkestan for the Silk Road sights or North to Karaganda and Astana (not much to see but surprisingly cool during summer due it being very windy).

Obviously this is a very packed itinerary for a two-months, so you want to drop destinations and flesh out your stay at others.
You can do 4 out of 5 countries in less than 24 hours (by bus and taxi between Khujand TJ and Bishkek KG), but that's neither relaxing nor recommended.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>Where would you spend most of your time?
It really depends on what you like:
Like mountains? Then you'll have the best time in Kyrgyzstan where you can spend months in the mountains if you desire.
Like history that isn't just rock carvings and shards? You'll be best served with Uzbekistan, both the "Big Three" and smaller destinations like the countless fortresses in the desert.

All countries but Turkmenistan give you ample time to visit and visa runs can be had for cheap.

It is really easy to go country collecting (my passport has pages and pages filled with entry and exit stamps due to extended weekend trips), but in the end you do not want to rush from one place to the next because of a tight itinerary.
Yes, you can visit Khiva/Bukhara in one day, but strolling through town in the late evening or early morning with nobody else in sight is something you can only do if you spend a night or two there.
The same can be said about chilling on the shores of Issyk-Kul or spending a lazy day in a yurt camp reading a book while listening to nature.

Anyway, let me know if you want to know more about a place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Food wise, how’s the food?
There's a reason why the region isn't a gourmet travel destination: The local dishes aren't much to write home about.
You'll have a lot of meat and grease and many dishes will start to feel similar after being here for some time.
The good thing is that the Soviet time brought foreign dishes that are now a staples of the local diet everywhere.
One of them are salads influenced by ethnic Koreans, available in all bazaars, most restaurants, delicatessen and supermarkets.
On a regular day, at least one of my meals contains whatever kind of salad I feel like that day. On bazaars they're usually home-made, sold by middle-aged women, most of them will let you try before buying, use that opportunity to sample, same applies for confectionery sold there.
I personally avoid "Pizza&Sushi" places, most of them don't do either right. Bigger cities have both proper pizzerias and sushi bars if you want to mix things up a little.

People are very proud of their bread (pic related), try to spot the differences between regions.
Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan have surprisingly good dairy products, just be aware that they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West.
Try whatever produce is in season, local fruits and vegetables are usually very tasty and fresh due to short supply chains. Again, they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West, probably because the local agriculture is less developed and therefore uses fewer modern preservatives.

If you're taking the train, take some vegetables, fruits and bread to share because the locals love to feed foreigners and see their reactions to local food and it's nice to be able to share as well.
Trains always have hot water, so instant noodles and mashed potatoes will be a safe backup.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>What I can’t absolutely miss?
Try the "signature dishes" of the region like plov, lagman, beshparmak, manty, samsa.
Eat the ones you like again, preferably at small places, the shorter the menu, the better the dishes.

In Kyrgyzstan, especially in Issyk-Kul you have to try Ashlan-Fu (pic related), a Chinese-style cold noodle soup with vinegar (works very well for hangovers).
In Tajikistan you have to try Kurutob, a salad made from bread that for some reason you can't find in the neighbouring countries.
Don't forget about local minorities: Uyghurs and Dungans have some nice dishes, as have the ethnic Koreans that operate the Korean restaurants found in every bigger city.

If it's your first trip to the former USSR then you should definitely try what the other republics have to offer, be it Moldovan/Georgian/Azeri wine, Russian and Georgian cuisine or just plain old Ukrainian sweets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Also, is there a sim card that works in all of them?
It's cheaper and less hassle to buy a SIM card in each country than to see what roaming offers are available.
Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan can be annoying by requiring a hardware registration if you want to use a local SIM card for more than a month.
You can avoid that by roaming using a Kyrgyz SIM card, but that's too much of a hassle unless you're living in Kyrgyzstan, especially since you'll need to figure out the offers and how to top up from abroad if needed.
Roaming from abroad is usually expensive, the least expensive place for Europeans being Kazakhstan, in the rest of the region a local SIM card reigns supreme.
If you're just passing through Turkmenistan then you shouldn't waste your time hunting for a SIM card, if you're on a tour then your guide will be able to help you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370901
You're going to be spending some money - a budget tour of 4 days and 3 nights from a Western agency runs about 1000 dollars, for an additional 400 dollars you'll get 8 nights and 9 days in the country.
Obviously some local tour operator might be able to shave off some dollars from the quoted prices above, but most of the costs are set by the Turkmen government, so no getting around that.
This is the major reason why transit visa runs through the country are popular, you save money and have more (limited) freedom to choose your way through the country.

Any well-stocked tour agency can book you a tour to Turkmenistan, they all need to cooperate with some companies within the country that can issue the relevant invitation letters.
Have a look on the internet what interests you and get quotes from different companies, no need to pay more for the same service.
Caravanistan might start up their middleman services once the country opens and they get confirmations of things running again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2373361
Anywhere that has a decent amount of hostels will be good. If a country doesn't have hostels then that's a pretty good indicator that it's a "hard" country to travel in. So type a country on booking dot com then filter for hostels only and see how many options there are.

However, in a more general sense, I think it's simply a good idea to go places that aren't particularly far away from you because that just makes your first time a little nicer and easier. Spending 25 hours to get there and then spending 25 hours to get back is ok, but when you were only there for 15 days it's a bit shit. I know you said you don't want latin america, but somewhere like Belize, Costa Rica etc. would probably be good (not that I know much about those countries), they're nearby, I imagine visa wouldn't be too hard for you as a US citizen and they're different enough culturally that it will be an interesting experience. Booking has a lot of options for hostels in costa rica and panama which tells me that they're good countries for doing this in.

Hostels are a good general tip as well, since if you stay in one you will meet people who can give you inspiration on where to go, or meet people to eat with or go party with etc. A lot of people are scared of staying in shared accommodation or they think only stoner hippies use it, but that's far from the truth, I'd recommend at least trying a few hostels if you're unsure about them. Travelling alone doesn't necessarily mean being alone.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2367756
There's not much to tell. Probably a meme story on /trv. I went through a long list of terrible life events, both by my own fault and out of my control. Hated my job and considered quitting but I was terminated before I had the chance. I had severance pay and nothing else going for me. My apartment lease was up and I moved my stuff to storage, decided to go to Japan for a few months and maybe end it afterwards or along the way. Once in Japan, I spent a week or two adjusting, and I realized that having daily challenges in life made existential problems go on the back burner.
Met a girl on Tinder while it still was a "friend finder" in Asia. Used her as a tour guide and went to a love hotel a few times. It was casual and I met another girl, who was clingy and (I soon discovered) crazy. Met another. Made friends with Japanese guys and girls (and some expats) and developed a social circle - which didn't last longer than my trip, but amazed me by how easy it was when I wasn't wrapped up in my own head.
Decided that life really wasn't so bad, at least as long as it stayed interesting. And decided not to kill myself and instead looked for ways to earn a living remotely. Applied for jobs until I got one.
In my opinion, the destination I chose was irrelevant. I'd often thought to myself "before I kill myself, I'll go to X country/location". They've varied over the years: California, Africa, India, Japan. When it was time, my destination was Japan. I guess I didn't really want to die because instead of taking the quick jump off an expressway bridge, I actually visited the destination I'd dreamed about. I'm glad I did, and now many years later, I've got kids and I'm happier than I've ever been before. Happier than many of my old friends back in my home country. I wouldn't change a thing.

>It amazed me how easy it was when I wasn't wrapped up in my own head

This is exactly why I urge people to go backpacking. When you spend a couple weeks (or months, or years) doing the backpacking thing, every day offers something new and you get a new perspective on your problems. I can't explain why, maybe it's because when you're backpacking you tend to make last minute decisions ("Fuck it, I'll skip Nice and take the train to Marseille!") and that makes you realise that you can make decisions about the more important things in your life too.
There is a phenomenon that astronauts come back to Earth with a greater interest in environmental concerns, altruism etc. Because seeing the whole world as just a ball of blue and green has some crazy effects on their beliefs. I think backpacking is kind of similar.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Favorite:
>Chhattisgarh, India: rural and predominately tribal state in east-central India. The whole area has a bad reputation for insurgency and violence, which keeps most visitors away. However, the entire region is incredibly beautiful, insofar it's heavily forested, mountainous, and incredibly biodiverse. It also has some of the most unique and isolated cultures in the entirety of "mainland" India. People are very, very friendly, but not in the obnoxious, quasi-autistic way that North Indians can be friendly. Locals can be a little suspicious of outsiders, but there's zero hassle or harassment. The tribals also make really good alcohol, kek
>Turkey: First country I ever visited outside of the United States. I went for the first time in 2013 and stayed in Istanbul for about a year in 2020-2021. IMO, it's one of the most-visited countries in the world for a reason: the people are extraordinarily hospitable, especially outside of big cities, and the entire country is drop-dead gorgeous. Istanbul is probably--and unironically--one of the most naturally beautiful urban areas in the world. Great views everywhere, reasonably safe, and cheap AF due to the ongoing lira crisis
>Colombia + Mexico: hard tie, can't really pick which I prefer. I'm not a coomer, I just really liked the sort of energy and vibrancy in most big, Latin American cities. If I had to choose one of the two, I'd probably go with Mexico, just because the food is so much better

The center of Athens has been taken over by immigrants, mostly shitty Pakistanis and Bangladeshis. Greeks have fled the center of Athens to further away exurbs like Korydallos, Marousi, Kifissia, Lagonisi, Gylfada, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous

Btw, I don't want to screw anyone over with this post:

I am not saying or recommending to stay at those exburbs which are further away from almost all the tourist destinations you will want to visit. They are also further from the cultural events if you know Greek.

If you have more money it is probably better to stay in Monastiraki or Plaka that are in the city center but still too expensive for the Islamic riff raff to swarm on the property market. If you have less money it is probably better to stay in Exarcheia which is much cheaper, but poor Greek hippies, arthouse types, anarchists and communists still live there which limits the Islamic floodgate.

I personally have chosen a hotel in the center of Pakistan in Greece, Metaxourgeio. But I know Greek and much more interested in participating in Greek language nightlife(theater, concerts, etc.) and the city center is still closer where most of those venues are located. The nearby subway also has just a few stops till it connects to Trainose(suburban rail line), Omonia, Syntagma, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2352845
It depends.

Your experience will be completely determined by your placement, something which you have very, very little control over. I cannot stress enough that EVERY placement is different and unique it its own way and you'll really have no idea what you've gotten yourself into until you get there.

Some places you'll work for a single school, others you'll go to five different schools a week (one girl I knew was going to eleven different schools a month).

Some places your fellow teachers will be really cool and friendly, others you'll literally never be spoken to in the staff room.

Some places will expect you to spend all of your work time making lessons, attending club activities, and grading assignments, others literally do not care what you do the rest of the day so long as you show up on time to your scheduled classes.

Some places will subsidize your rent, help you rent a car, and open your bank account for you, others will literally put it in your contract that you are not allowed behind the wheel of an automobile during your time as their employee.

For what it's worth I did JET for four years and had a great time, I was placed in a fairly small city but my support network (managers, school administration) was outstanding and more than made up for the shortcomings that came with my placement (mainly a lack of nightlife). But for every story like mine there's a guy that got handed a shit sandwich and broke contract six months in, so YMMV.

I've been meaning to ask

How do you guys plan lessons? I'm trying to be an ESL teacher right out of college and my TEFL course was alright but I still feel kinda underprepared. I have good ideas for activites but I struggle on differentiating between the Practice and presentation parts of the PPP structure they want me to use.

Do you guys just use resources and lesson plans the school gives you for lessons and just act them out or do you use google/textbooks and plan during office hours?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It depends on where you are working. Most established language schools will have their own bare-bone lesson plans. Most proper schools will use a recognized curriculum, like Cambridge Curriculum or something like that. If you are going somewhere and given no directions whatsoever, then torrent some TEFL lesson plans (they clearly don't expect even that much effort on your part), or download/buy appropriate level and subject Cambridge Curriculum and write some plans based on that - their instructor guides only give broad strokes, so unless you can improvise unusually well for a rookie, you should do up the first week's worth of lesson plans and see how effective they are (and most importantly, if they are too long or too short).
Also prepare at least ten different extension activities, games, etc, for when you are on the spot and need something productive to fill the time. They are definite lifesavers. For really disorganized "conversational" teaching positions, that might actually be all you really need. Get a couple of books of those and you're done.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Well after getting my CerTESOL I taught in Korea for two yea at a hagwon. I took a few trips but honestly found the country to be pretty boring and uninteresting, and I didn't really have time to travel anyways. So I just decided to save money and spend it elsewhere. My only real expense was groceries and the occasional night out, so it was easy to save ~$1800 a month. I just sent my whole salary home every month and barely touched it.

After that I went to work in Vietnam. Got a job teaching at a good language center since I had IELTS experience from my certification. Initially took a pay hit, but the hourly rate was way higher and I didn't have to work as much. Plus cheaper cost of living. Once I got my hours up to around 20-25 I was making more than Korea. And since your employer doesn't own your visa like in Korea you can hustle if you want for extra cash. Saved about $1500 a month maybe since I traveled a lot more and had to pay rent.

Now I work at a private school in Thailand making about the same as Vietnam, but with more work since I'm salaried and have to be at school all day. I like the routine better though since I hate hourly work with timetabling and subbing and all that other bullshit. Probably going to stay here for a bit then try to get a scholarship for an MA TESOL or diploma or something. We'll see.

Anyways on a TEFL salary spending vs. saving is really just a lifestyle. I'm frugal I guess but I'm not miserly. I spend a lot when I'm in vacation mode, but I only really travel to cheap locations. Last vacation was to India for a month where I spent maybe $2000. Most of my hobbies are cheap and I don't splurge when I go out. When I first started working I tracked my spending and just eliminated all the useless shit that was wasting a ton of money (alcohol, subscriptions, ordering food etc...). Doesn't seem hard to me but I guess a lot of people struggle with saving and lifestyle creep is a real thing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2357524
Go to medical school, if that really is an option. Your work will be much more fulfilling and stable. You can also pack up and move to most places in the world (barring developed countries, unless you jump through a lot of hoops) if you are a licensed doctor in your home country and speak English as well as you do now. Just buckle down and put in the work. You won't regret going to medical school (if you graduate it and pass your licensing exams), but it's very likely you'll regret becoming an English teacher because you're romanticizing it.
Teaching English for most Westerners who do it is a means to an end - they do it because it has a low bar to entry and allows them to live abroad. Most leave after a couple of years, and they have the ability to return to a developed country and all the opportunities that gives them (whether they realize it or not). If they really are passionate about teaching, they could become licensed teachers, but the vast majority do not. The same would probably happen to you, except you have less chance of success than they do (non-native speaker, non-Anglo passport) and much greater opportunity cost (giving up chance of medical school).
TL;DR - go to medical school.

I'm also worried about being placed in the middle of nowhere with no nightlife or anyway for me to go out and meet people. I know, kind of contradicts the last point but again, I'm working on it. I honestly think I would be fine with going anywhere that has a decent sized college with young people near it, as hopefully there'll be some nightlife.

I actually do have some teaching experience. I've worked as a sub at my old school (Both middle & high school). It was an easy job for the most part, the teachers would leave work for me and I just made sure the kids did it. I enjoyed it for the most part. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2361068
I'm sure you realize it's hard to give you life advice with only a few paragraphs of information. I'll try as best I can:

> I'm also worried about being placed in the middle of nowhere
This is only relevant if you apply to government run programs that don't allow you to select your location (i.e. JET or EPIK). If you apply to something like a hagwon, buxiban, language center etc... you can choose where you want to work. But if this is a major concern you would have to do a fair bit of research prior to accepting a contract. The size of a city or the presence of a college nearby doesn't necessarily mean there will be great opportunities for you to socialize.

It's good that you have some teaching experience, so you can be confident you won't shit your pants in front of the class. Entry-level ESL jobs can be similarly "easy", in the sense that you are often given a curriculum and your only job is to get the students to fill out their books while avoiding any major complaints. However, this isn't always the case - there are many jobs that will expect you to make your own lessons and deliver them without assistance. Teaching ESL isn't necessarily difficult but it can often be unintuitive, so if you find yourself in a more serious position you might struggle with high expectations and pressure.

Are you looking to make teaching a career? Are you just concerned about money or the stigma of being unemployed? Do you have any interest in ESL in general?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2361068
>>2361140
One option would be to do a CELTA or CertTESOL. These are short, rigorous courses that will teach you the basics and get you comfortable in an ESL classroom. They are expensive, but definitely worth a consideration if this is something you are seriously considering doing for at least a few years. It would be better to do the course and find out that TEFL is not for you, than to fly to another country to work and discover it there.

Of course, you should keep in mind that you can always quit a job. In the worst case scenario where you are miserable/depressed in a foreign country, you can just head to the airport and get on the first flight home. It is a bit pathetic and unprofessional, but I say it to emphasize that you are never trapped if you feel like you've made a mistake.

As far as social life is concerned, it's basically impossible to predict how you might react in a foreign environment. Some people who are normally shy and reclusive rise to the occasion, and some people who are gregarious find themselves socially isolated. Your social life isn't a permanent state either; foreign friends will come and go, local friends will lose interest or move away. How things start isn't necessarily how they end up. Part of your success in this area is obviously a function of effort, but it could just as much be attributed to chance. Have you heard the parable of the old man who lost his horse?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2362122
They have thousands of centers all over the world. You can go to the Cambridge website and select a country to look at where the course is available. Then you'd go to that center's website to book a course. The price will vary based on where you are and who you do it with, so you can shop around if you're tight on cash. But expect at least a couple thousand dollars plus travel/living expenses. They're "UK-based" because the course is moderated by Cambridge and they provide all the material, testing and verification. I think during COVID they started offering courses online, so that might also be an option if you'd prefer it.

There's also the CertTESOL which is pretty much the same thing. It's a little more onerous and the curriculum is slightly different, but the certificates are basically interchangeable. It might be cheaper depending on where you go, I'm not sure.

Anyways what a lot of people do is to take the course in the country they plan on teaching in. So you could do it in Vietnam and then look for work right afterwards. Many course providers will help you find work or even offer you a job outright after the class is finished. This isn't possible in Japan/Korea though because of visa laws.

>>2353223

I've nearly gone into EPIK and work as a teacher in my home country.

I tried Korvia, got an interview with An Park, she wanted me to speak Korean with her in the interview and was like asking questions about my relationship with the Korean GF.

EPIK / GOE should have fairly typical hours like 8-5/6 which is not too bad, you will have lesson breaks to plan and stuff like that, which makes your job easier than a hagwon.

Co-teachers will be either helpful or unhelpful from what I have heard. If you translate your role into English, it's something like English instructor, you get an E2 visa for the job which means you are limited to teaching English conversation. Most places just expect you to make English fun for the kids and enjoyable to learn.

Not sure on the classes per day, it probably varies between schools (you don't get a choice on where you go besides general location).

Orientation is your training days on what to do and so on. You might have to give some fun demo lessons, basically go learn and network with other English teachers. You will want to form a network with them and if you can exchange resources and so on, then you will have an easy time.

They should give you resources if they really want their students and their English communication skills to improve, but most places probably just want a white person to be entertaining their kids with English games.

Lesson planning at first is hard, but after you get to know your classes, you will find it easier to plan. If the school rotates classes through and they're all at the same level of English speaking ability, then you could make one lesson with varying levels of difficulty where the little kids get the easiest form and the older kids get the harder form with more vocabulary and complex expressions.

In your video, just smile and show that you are a fun person. Say how you love Korea and want to be there and how it is such a nice country and how you would love to be there.

>>2369868
I'll add to this because I've worked in Cambodia and know teachers in Laos. For the majority of people, working in either country is basically volunteering and earning enough to cover your expenses and live okay by local standards - i.e. not enough for your flights. There are decent jobs but you will need a degree for them. When I worked in Cambodia, I was at a university in the countryside and got just over $1000/month. It was a cushy gig but there are maybe 20 jobs like that in the entire country. The majority of English teachers are backpackers or retirees who wound up in the country and earn $500/month. To get those jobs you just need to be in the country.
It's similar in Laos - there's a handful of good jobs in Vientiane, but they aren't hiring people without degrees and experience. A big difference from Cambodia is the government doesn't make it easy for backpackers to get hired. Most English teachers in Laos are more likely to be with volunteer agencies and NGOs than anything else.
Having said all of that, you could lie about your degrees and experience, but you'd have to be pretty convincing to get through the interviews. I'd say most of these positions are filled by referrals.
And that part about needing to be snowflake white is just hyperbole. Yeah, it looks good, but most teachers in these countries are tanned golden. Looks do matter but I had an ugly old African guy as a colleague. Of course, he had a degree, and probably an impressive resume... until something happened that sent him to a backwater university in Cambodia.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2370297
Yes, as of mid-2021 (last time I was offered a job in Vietnam), your TEFL cert needed to be apostilled. I have an online groupon from a company based in the UK. If I was going to accept the job in Vietnam, I needed to order a certified copy from the UK accreditation agency, have it sent to a UK apostille company, and they would apostille it and send it to me. (The company was apostille dot org dot uk and quoted me 61 pounds.) It all would have cost about 4-5 times the original TEFL cost. Getting my degree apostilled was much more expensive because first I needed to make a notarized copy (I wasn't going to apostille the original) and the Viet embassy in my home country wanted me to use one of their suggested apostille companies, all of which pushed this cost into a few hundred dollars.
BTW, you can absolutely hunt for a job on the ground in Vietnam, but if you want to switch to a work visa you'd be advised to get your degree and TEFL cert apostilled before you arrive because they want them apostilled in the country they were issued in. Anything else can be done in Vietnam, including the criminal background check.

No, the average is about $1800. If recruited from outside the country right now, it's $1400-1500. There's some things to keep in mind:

- there are easy jobs (read slides for 20 hours a week) and hard jobs (lesson plan and deal with tiger moms) that pay the same amount
- unlimited side work paying $20/hr (in English centers) and $25+/hr (private tutoring)
- you can switch from a $1400 shit job to an $1800/month easy job once you're on a work visa, regardless of what your employer claims

So yes, there are some people earning $3000/month just white face teaching, but they're working 6-7 days/week. Though they can save most of that, depending on their lifestyle

>>2373057
In the realm of teaching, any master's degree is a bazillion times better than no master's degree. Just like not having an undergrad keeps you from certain teaching jobs (actually about 98% of teaching jobs), not having a graduate degree keeps you out of most (but not all) university jobs. Those extra "MA" letters at the end of your name, besides making you look like a douche if you use them in your signature, also open up doors faster if you make this a career. The fact that your graduate program has the word "English" is a great bonus.
Will it help your entry-level job prospects? Either not at all or a helluva lot. Depends on the randomness factor of who looks at your application. I'd say it will average out as "a little". It won't hurt your prospects.

Short answer, yes.
An MA in International Relations or something is just as good or better than an MSc in Medical Sciences or Engineering, far as academic degrees for TEFL are concerned (because most are expecting an MA, not MSc).
What matters is you tick the box as a graduate teacher, which is pretty much a professor in many countries. With that and a simple CELTA you are pretty much equivalent to a DELTA.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2373853
In most countries, this is a technical requirement that you are MA level educated to hold the position.
This is why a DELTA (being of equivalent Ofqual) will satisfy this, as will any other unrelated Master's degree, so long as you have one.
You can literally have an MBA (academic "level" qualification) and CELTA (actual skillset qualification) and you're good to teach uni level in most of Asia, on paper (and therefore, in practice).
Of course a relevant diploma will be preferred, but in terms of strictly satisfying the requirements you're halfway there, just need a decent TEFL.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
of course if you are interested in medieval castles thats fine - but also consider other historical structures - ruins, cathedrals, palaces, fortifications, grand houses, industrial revolution marvels etc

In London's sphere - Tower of london is in the heart of the city, very tourist but lots of history. Day trips there are Leeds castle (not the location of the city of Leeds), Dover castle (also famous cliffs, allegedly a shit city), Windsor castle (royal residence), Bodiam Castle (great moat), Winchester Castle (not as striking outside structure but still a historical town)

Warwick castle in the centre of country is famous.

Gwynedd region of north wales has like 7 castles built to solidify english rule over wales - Caenarfon famous prince of wales inauguration site, but also ones like Conwy, Beaumaris, Harlech. There are other smaller structures. Snowdonia mountain in the backdrop (there is a train up the mountian but closed for winter)
conwy and caenarfon have city walls
not far Chester has medeival town center

Scotland - travel at new years eve "Hogmanay" is arguably a bigger holiday for them than christmas
Edinburgh Castle is in heart of city - but also Holyrood Palace is a royal residence in edinburgh (1600s) plus edinburgh has old town and new town both unesco areas.
Short trip to Sterling another city around a castle.
Short trip to Glasgow - in the periphery of the city is Bothwell Castle ruins however it is not a traditional tourist draw for glasgow.

Northumbria
Newcastle is a neat town but the castle is underwhelming
Durham is a castle kind of more cathedral
Alnwick castle
Bamburgh castle
Holy Island (first viking invasion?)
Berwick Upon Tweed - has bastion fort walls
Carlisle is 1hr from newcastle, has ancient castle too, also not far from hardians wall sites

York has city walls, and a fortified central "castle", also grand cathedral, ruined abbey, and roman and viking history, and a medieval street

there is more

I'd say hire a car if you can. Remember trains are always jam packed that time of year. Due to the strikes, there will be the same number of people crammed onto fewer trains. And of course trains won't get you everywhere, especially when you're hoping to see castles.
Also remember - if there are strikes, the days either side are impacted too.
eg. If there's a strike on a Wednesday, things slow down from Tuesday afternoon/evening, and then there's usually considerable disruption the next day.
Lastly, trains in this country cost an absolute fortune. You'd probably be cheaper just hiring a car.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2371266
>medieval castles
fly to edinburgh. within edinburgh it's self there is 2 great castles, edinburgh castle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburgh_Castle) (the best castle in the UK imo) & craigmillar castle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Craigmillar_Castle).
Edinburgh old town is basically one giant open air medieval museum, which people live in. The museum of Scotland is also worth a visit, it's free and one of the best museums in europe.
Edinburgh in general is spectacular in the winter.

40 minutes on the train or an hour on the bus and you'll be in Stirling, and Stirling castle (the second best castle in the UK imo) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stirling_Castle).
You could also head up into the highlands where there are a variety of castles dating from prehistoric (brochs) up to late medieval (forts) and everything in-between, set amongst some of the most incredible dramatic scenery you've ever seen. Though to do this during late December i'd recommend you rent a 4x4 with winter tyres. Public transport up that way is sparse at the best of times, let alone in the depths of winter.

Alternatively you could head down into the lovely and often overlooked scottish borders, where you can find a variety of castles and tower forts linked to the lawless and violent history of the border regions, not to mention several incredible medieval monasteries. All this is set amongst beautiful prime rolling british countryside and charming little villages.
very comfy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Other famous landmarks

Cornwall area
Tintagel Castle "king arthur birth place" a tin mining settlement since roman era.
Saint Michaels Mont (the less exciting version of french mont saint michel?)

More London and surrounding area
Hampton Court Palace - famous for Henry VIII era
Rochester Castle another Norman Castle, some neat details like one of the towers is round vs square
Canterbury has cathedral and tries to do medievl town feel

Avebury - is maybe the most famous megalithic structure after stonehenge,
Nearest "city" to stonehenge is Salisbury which is is another famous cathedral town but there are like a dozen famous cathedrals in uk.
Old Sarum is an archeological site of an abandoned hill fortification
Bath is not far from this area - most famous for most of the town being georgian era architecture, but there is also the excavated roman baths.
And surrounding area of Cotswolds which have many little villages with famous cottages - expensive and more an old people attraction, even for history autists.
Wells - very small town famous cathedral, but also has things like oldest residential street in europe

The famous university towns have great architecture - within one uni they will have different colleges that the old ones have their own minicampus with a medieval chapel type of thing.
Cambridge - king's college has the most famous building prob. Nearby towns like ely and bury st edmund have nice cathedrals. Far from here but close to nowhere there is Sutton Hoo - anglo saxon burial site found on some family cottage property - they made netflix movie The Nig about it.

Outside Oxford, there is Blenheim Palace (Churchill family) - biggest non royal estate in uk i think.
stratford upon avon - will try to have the medieval look, leaning into shakespere heritage.

I don't think i'd go in winter - but the biggest concentration of prehistoric structures is Orkney islands with skara brae being msot famous.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Born and raised in Albuquerque (Have also traveled a lot)
It’s very beautiful, also the 5th largest state so don’t expect to see everything in one trip. Coming from Colorado I recommend you start in Taos, kinda hippy dippy place but the natural setting is staggeringly beautiful. Try to see the Taos pueblo although it’s been closed a lot lately so check ahead. You could do santa fe but that place bugs the shit out of me, very expensive and filled (i mean filled) with white texas/california tourists. If you do go there I recommend the Rail yard and upper canyon road. If you’re into history La Cienaguilla petroglyphs are cool and like 15 minutes from the plaza. I highly highly recommend the Valles Caldera, you can drive in from Los Alamos and soak it in. Stop in Jemez Springs on your way down, you can check out the historic sight or just hangout at the biker bar. From their you can either go to Albuquerque or up 550 towards Farmington. If you’re headed that way go to chaco canyon. It’s a heavy place but one of the most interesting sights in all of north america. Assuming you’re gonna pass through albuquerque I recommend stopping at the frontier and getting green chili stew or enchiladas. it’s cheap it’s fast and the vibes inside are all the best of albuquerque. You’ll like it, it’s not as shit as everyone says but be aware of burglary, they won’t rob you directly but they’ll smash your window as soon as you turn around. Park near other cars and in the light you’ll be fine it’s never happened to me in over 20 years of living in ABQ.

nature fag here, been to NM a few times, underrated place. Carlsbad Caverns is great, one of my favorite national parks. Easily my favorite cave I've been in, only good cave I've been to that you don't need to be on a guided tour also which is nice, though there are guided tours to other parts of the cave also. Haven't even seen the bat flight at Carlsbad since I always go to NM in winter when I'm snowed out from places further North, heard it's great though, must be if it's anything like the bird flights you can see at Bosque del Apache. Definitely recommend Bosque del Apache in winter, even if you're not really into birds or nature, seeing thousands or tens of thousands of large birds take flight is a special experience.
White Sands is neat enough, worth a stop.
The Sangre de Cristos around Taos are nice, nothing specatcular though, I find Valles Calderas more interesting.
The Gila Canyon area is beautiful, Jordan hot springs is an excellent backcountry hot springs, it's an adventure to get there though, if you're into backpacking at all it's a great area.
Northwest New Mexico has a lot of Badlands with crazy formations, pretty cool. Chaco Canyon is nice too, largest pueblo ruins I think, Not as scenic as Mesa Verde in Colorado but you can walk through them on your own which is nice. Lots of other Native American ruins around New Mexico also.
I've somehow neer even driven through Albuquerque or Santa Fe, I'd like to see the balloon festival sometime.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2373708
We are actually planning our next big trip and it's going to be 10.5 months. We try to take long trips when we are doing big life changes. ie: moving to a new city. While everything is packed up on boxes, you might as well just store it and go. The boxes don't give a shit how much dust they collect. You don't lose your job because you are already going to quit when moving between cities.

I plan these big ones years in advance and save diligently for them, where we go has a huge impact. The best example of that is our upcoming trip is 10.5 months and a grand total of 30 days is in Europe, 5 days in Singapore, 3 Weeks in Taiwan, and 1 Week in Ireland. Otherwise, most of our time is spent in cheap places like Turkey, Kazakhstan, Basic Bitch SEA (Vietnam, Thailand, Cambodia), Philippines, and Indonesia. The last trip, we spent in 3 of the 7.5 months in India, and only 3 weeks in the Galapagos. And those were spent island hopping between the main islands and not on some gay overpriced boomer Galapagos cruise.

The first 7.5 month trip cost about $12,000 leafbux (per person), and this 10.5 one I am estimating at $17,500 Leafbux (per person). I started planning for the first one almost 4 years in advance, and I started planning our current trip late 2020. We don't leave until June 2024 so again, 4 years. We are both STEM professionals so its not hard to save $3,000 a year for it, but obviously the ability to do it will vary with each person. Beyond that, we are just frugal, we don't do gay tourist shit that costs $$$ and don't stay in hotels (hostels mostly, private rooms or not, depends) and we eat cheap. We don't deprive ourselves of things but we just make sure to do what we can to be cost efficient.

As far as getting sick of it, sometimes it's nice to just get a slightly nicer place for a few days and spend it watching TV only going out for food, but I would rather walk around an old ruins any day than do excel spreadsheets for some faggot boss.

It was absolutely amazing to the point of being comical—the suite had a sort of personal concierge/butler assigned to it— but I don’t need to do it again. I can just speak for myself in saying, as someone else who has lived in London, there is very little there that doesn’t feel insanely corporatised, forced and frankly soulless.

You can pop up as many quirky new bars, regurgitated thrift shops and over-priced market stalls as you want, at the end of the day it can’t replace the essence of what makes somewhere a nice place to live with a good quality of living.

Let me give you an example. I lived in Madrid, every day after finishing work, I’d leave my apartment, (lived in a variety of different areas, all of them vibrant, visually beautiful and safe) - not something that you’ll find in London under a comparable income, go out around 10 or 11 at night, grab a coffee outside any number of hundreds of nice bar cafes in the area within short walking distance, relax, smoke and make conversation outside in a nice plaza or old winding street. Wide variety of folks, old young, locals, expats etc, never a bad vibe, nobody trying to prove anything or be someone like I often find in London.

No trashy halal chicken shops, lots of genuine cultural events (live Spanish music etc) mostly actual, local Spanish folks and lots of families about everywhere.

Recently I was dead central London, Friday night. Tried to do the same thing, walked around for fucking ages and couldn’t find a single spot where I could even sit down. Everything closed except for a few pubs which were pretty dull with a handful of toffs.

Found a place finally on Google, looked okay. I get there and there’s a bouncer at the door, asks if I’m a “member” and then tells me to go away when I tell him I’m not.

One more thing about London is that the vibe is just completely off. Full of condescending, passive aggressive cunts.

Visiting smaller cities in the UK, and even more small towns where there aren’t many options for clubs/bars, pubs are awesome at night and become my go-to. Very social places, lots of young people, good music, plenty of socialising etc.

When I went to a few of these pubs in central, it was mostly older 50+ banker types having a few pints with their colleagues or a few old upper-middle class couples sitting down sharing a wine or whatever. Completely and utterly different vibe. Not to mention they start winding down past 11 and are usually completely closed by 12 at most, even on a Friday night.

Regardless though, that pavement coffee culture is fucking amazing. It really makes you feel part of the city, being able to be out in the open in your surroundings whilst being able to admire the architecture and your surrounding neighbourhood. Meeting people outside too is so much of a nicer experience and is so much more chilled out.

I’ll say as well, walking in a pub by yourself, whilst there’s nothing wrong with it, can be a weird experience. Sitting down at a table outdoors by yourself and getting a coffee and a smoke feels a lot less intimidating and normal, at least to me.

Going to chile this weekend and next week. Feedback requested from people familiar with the country

>Santiago (What to do here near the airport?)
From Santiago to Punta Arenas
Magdalena Island for penguins
Catch a bus to Puerto Natales,
Stay at Puerto Natales and then bus into Torres Del Paine for a day hike at either Mirador Base Las Torres or Grey Glacier (Not sure which hike would be better)
Go back to Punta Arenas, fly up to Puerto Montt
Stay over at a lodge and ascend volcano osorno the next morning.
Begin return home.
